newsitem.title: USA: Technology shares slip amid profit concerns.
newsitem.headline: Technology shares slip amid profit concerns.

text.p: Shares of bellwether technology stocks slipped Tuesday for a second day amid concerns that company earnings may not justify record-high share prices.

While the biggest companies in software, semiconductors, networking and personal computers are enjoying huge backlogs and strong business, many smaller vendors are not, analysts said. That is prompting some investors to reconsider pouring money into technology just before the holidays.

"The move in these stocks borders on madness," said William Fleckenstein, principal of Fleckenstein Capital Inc. in Seattle. "Anyone who checks out now is not going to be sorry about six months from now."
Shares of Intel Corp, the world's biggest computer chipmaker, fell 2 to 119-1/2 in early afternoon trading of 6.51 million. The stock was the most active on the Nasdaq market.
Microsoft Corp, the biggest personal computer software company, sagged 5/8 to 152-7/8.
Compaq Computer Corp, the biggest personal computer marker, was down 1 at 77-7/8.
And Cisco Systems Inc, whose networking devices control most of the information flow through the Internet, was down 1-1/8 at 66-1/4.
Each of these bellwethers has seen its stock surge more than 50 percent this year amid booming business.
"We're still very bullish on technology," particularly Intel, said Richard Gochman, executive vice president of Tanaka Capital Management in New York.
But the smaller vendors in the semiconductor, software, PC and networking niches are struggling to keep up with the leaders, analysts said.
The backlog at Applied Materials Inc, a manufacturer of chipmaking equipment, is much smaller than it was a couple of years ago, Fleckenstein said.
Some analysts said the technology rally may pause until after the new year as major investors decrease risk in their portfolios. But most technology leaders have solid fundamental business.
"As long as interest rates are down and mutual funds pour money, you're going to see these stocks go up," said Ed Bierdeman, technology analyst at Dakin Securities in San Francisco.
